HR 3 is bad policy. Plain and simple.

It will lead to hundreds of fewer cures.

It will snuff out the next cure for cancer or Alzheimer’s.

It will hurt small innovators, not big pharma.

And it’s based on a false choice of medical innovation vs. affordability. We can have both.

Do we want to lower drug prices? Of course we do. 

But we can do this by protecting innovation, promoting affordability of cures, and stopping pharmaceutical companies from engaging in unfair, uncompetitive behavior.

I detail our solutions in this op-ed.
https://www.houstonchronicle.com/opinion/outlook/article/dan-crenshaw-drug-prices-nancy-pelosi-GOP-DNC-15083691.php

Some make the argument that patients in other countries don’t pay as much as we do for drugs. Well, other countries don’t have access to the same drugs we do.

In fact, the majority of countries we model our pricing system on in this bill don’t even have 70% of the drugs we do. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_baLN8WQAEi3Aq.jpg

Moreover, this bill would harm small innovators, not big pharma.

This bill would “reduce by 88% the number of drugs brought to market by small and emerging companies in California alone.”

Democrats aren’t taking on big pharma like they say they are.

https://republicans-energycommerce.house.gov/news/in-the-news/stat-news-its-tiny-biotechs-not-big-drug-makers-that-fear-nuclear-winter-from-pelosis-drug-pricing-bill/

As Scott Gottlieb notes, the drugs lost would be the breakthrough treatments for diseases like cancer or Alzheimer’s because “if investors knew their returns would be capped, they would direct their investments toward safer projects with lesser payoffs.”

https://www.wsj.com/articles/price-controls-would-stifle-biotech-innovation-11576107863

This bill will lead to fewer cures, because no company will invest in R&D under HR 3.

CBO says it will be 30 fewer drugs over a decade.

The Council of Economic Advisers says it could be 100 fewer drugs.

I break the entire bill down in this video series
https://republicans-energycommerce.house.gov/news/press-release/crenshaw-joins-walden-to-provide-facts-on-pelosi-plan-for-fewer-cures/

With HR 3, Democrats want to give the federal government unprecedented power to set prices for drugs like they do in Canada.

It’s not a “negotiation,” as the left says. It’s just terrible policy that would destroy medical innovation.

We actually tried to pass a fix to high insulin prices that DEMOCRATS voted down last Congress.

The price control strategy you want would destroy the innovation of any new drugs. 

There’s a reason Canada only has access to 52% of the drugs Americans do.

Here’s why: https://twitter.com/berniesanders/status/1438522060519534592 QT @BernieSanders Let me ask you a question. Are you satisfied with a system that allows the pharmaceutical industry to charge you $98 for the same vial of insulin that the Canadian people get for about $12?

It was great meeting the team, thank you for all of your hard work to protect the Ipswich River. Count me as a partner.
Tomorrow the group and my friend @SenBruceTarr are holding a community meeting to try to build consensus around ways to protect the river. I’ll be following it closely.
The group also focuses on reducing the impact of climate change. The river experienced two severe droughts and then major flooding in the last few years.

For a small a mount of money, we can connect communities that receive water from other sources to each other, and potentially reduce costs if you factor in all the costs that go into getting clean water to families across our region.
The second strategy is helping communities find alternative supplies—expect more from me on that front in the next few months.

The first is reducing use. About 20 percent of the water taken from the river leaks out of the old pipes that carry it to your faucet—some of the pipes are so old they’re made of wood. And about half of the water taken from the river goes to watering lawns.
The team at @ipswich_river is fighting to protect the river. They have a 2-part strategy.
The river supplies 5 million people from Wilmington to Lynn with water, and that’s part of the problem. Because many communities draw from the river in the summer, it is drying up.

Today I met with the team at @ipswich_river, the protectors of the Ipswich River, one of the 10 most endangered rivers in the United States. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_bmZdZWYAME-_8.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_bmjwRWUAcN48S.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_bmyZlX0AMOJZg.jpg

By allowing these businesses to harness the power of energy efficiency and clean energy, these investments will make a real difference. I'll continue fighting for additional resources like this help our small businesses prosper and thrive.
New Salem Brewing in Meredith will receive a $11,907 to build a solar array on the roof of their building. As a result, the brewpub will save over $2.9K annually on energy bills.

Concord's Lewis Farm and Greenhouses is one of the area's last remaining farms and grows fresh produce through sustainable farming. This $6,426 investment will help it install a new solar array that offsets its energy costs and aids future expansion.

A $14,795 federal grant will make tremendous energy efficiency improvements to 131 Broad Street LLC in Hanover. By funding new air source heat pumps, insulation, windows & other renovations, this investment will help the property reduce its energy use by 42%.

Harrisville's Mayfield Farm is family-owned & known for its fruit orchards & delicious, quality farm-to-table food. A $11,907 grant will help install a new solar array that will generate nearly $6,000 worth of power, meeting the farm's energy & expansion needs.

Located in the heart of Gorham, Scoggins General Store is a local staple and a visitor destination. A $15,765 grant will help the store install a solar array that will generate more than 75% of its electricity needs & save more than $2.7K annually.
376 Court Street LLC in Laconia will receive $6,936 to install a roof-mounted solar array. This array will produce 95% of historical electrical needs and save the property $3K annually!
